Yep, that's exactly what that comparison does.=A0 It compares each and ever=
y byte (all their 
bits) from file to file.=A0 If the same bytes are in bot=
h files, in the same places, they are the same.=A0 One tiny little differen=
ce, and it tells you.

the=
mselves are different? If so, that would definitely satisfy me that

hing was the same.

    =

      If the audio had been resampled, you could expect less 
        byte=
s, or different bytes, but not the same number of the same 
        bytes.=
=A0 That's why comparing the bytes in both files can rule that 
        out=
, if no changes are found.

 =
             
                They are not necessarily the same bytes, but =
I 
                  was proposing a quick check just to see if the files w=
ere in 
                  the same ballpark.=A0 Look at it the other way: i=
f the 
                  number of bytes were DIFFERENT, than you'd know th=
e files HAD 
                  changed, and you could stop testing.=A0 But =
if the number 
                  of bytes are the same, it tends to indicat=
e the files are 
                  likely the same, but you still need a lo=
w level file 
                  comparison to be sure.

My method is to com=
pare the 
                  files using the CMP command in unix.=A0 There a=
re many 
                  programs to compare files, but you have to be ca=
reful not to 
                  use one that does a line-by-line compare (o=
r a comparison 
                  meant for text files), since text files c=
an be different at a 
                  low level, but look essential the s=
ame in an editor (because 
                  of the way spaces and tabs and=
 new lines work between editors 
                  and platforms).

But any=
way, the way to compare is with 
                  a program that can compa=
re binary files, not text 
                  files.

                    So if the number of 
                    bytes m=
atch then they are the same bytes? See where my 
                    confus=
ion comes in?
                    =A0
                    How does one do a=
 
                    bit-level comparison? Is there a program that does th=
at, or 
                    is there some way of comparison by looking at t=
he file's 
                    properties?

                      ----- 
                      Original Me=
ssage ----- 
                      From: 
                      Rj

  =
                    
                      
                        
      =
                  
                          A file's content, it's integri=
ty, is 
                            simply the bytes (and their bits) in th=
e file.=A0 
                            If the file's content integrity is =
changed, that is, 
                            by definition, changing the =
bytes.=A0 If the 
                            bytes in there are not change=
d, then that integrity 
                            has not changed.

It is=
 possible to mess with 
                            other things about a fi=
le (like its name, its 
                            suffix, or its ownershi=
p) but this does not effect 
                            the contents, and =
so would not affect that 
                            integrity, or the sou=
nd of the file (assuming you 
                            could read it at =
all after changing the ownership, 
                            or the suffi=
x, etc).

When you do your tests, 
                            if you canno=
t do a bit level comparison, I would 
                            recommend=
 at least checking the file sizes.=A0 If 
                            they =
are identical, there is a very high probability 
                          =
  that the content has not 
                            changed.

                             =
   
                                
                                
     =
                           
                                Yes you can tel=
l loss of quality 
                                by a bit-level compariso=
n.=A0 An audio file 
                                is just a file of byte=
s, that is later 
                                interpreted by an audio p=
layer.=A0 Two files 
                                with the exact same co=
ntents, whether they are 
                                audio or image or=
 a dababase or an exe, are 
                                indistinguishab=
le from each other.=A0 That 
                                is, if I copie=
d the contents of one to a new 
                                file, and t=
he contents of the other to a new 
                                file, an=
d asked you which file each came from, 
                                the=
re would be no way to tell.=A0 Even the 
                                au=
dio player could not tell.=A0 The data is 
                                =
identical, and so the sound (or the picture, 
                             =
   etc) would be identical.

Yes I did listen 
                            =
    to the results, but that is not the best test 
                        =
        (they sounded identical, but that is a 
                           =
     subjective opinion).=A0 The real test is 
                            =
    compring the contents.=A0 Identical contents 
                         =
       means indentical data, means identical 
                            =
    audio.

It is probably possible to set up 
                            =
    an email compression scheme that does do lossy 
                       =
         audio compression.=A0 My tests show my setup 
                    =
            does not.=A0 If you'd like me to help test 
                   =
             your setup, we can do that too. From what I see, 
            =
                    lossy compression from an attachment would be 
        =
                        very unusual.

ion, and once turning it

hey arrived at Yahoo. Once they came

                        =
        
                                For 
                             =
   executables, you may be right. However, for wav 
                       =
         files, the compression during email is not loss 
                 =
               less. 
                                =A0
                 =
               I used to 
                                think as you do, =
in that the emailed 
                                attachment=A0of a wav =
file would not loose 
                                anything. After a len=
gthy discourse with another 
                                member here, I=
 learned that I was wrong. The 
                                reason why=
=A0I did not realize it in the 
                                first place=
 is that when I would email a wav 
                                file, I =
would intentionally keep it in very 
                                small =
segments, to keep file size down. This was 
                               =
 just for ease of transfer. But because of this, 
                         =
       I had not experienced any noticeable 
                              =
  loss.
                                =A0
                               =
 Now it may 
                                be in some cases, depending on=
 the servers or 
                                what have you that the fil=
e goes through, that 
                                the loss may be less =
or more. But once the 
                                attachment is 
     =
                           downloaded,=A0the=A0quality=A0has been 
        =
                        found to be less then the original 
               =
                 wav.
                                =A0
                 =
               Again though 
                                you can only r=
eally tell when the=A0wav file 
                                is large.
 =
                               =A0
                                ----- Or=
iginal Message ----- 
                                
                    =
            From: 
                                Rj 
                    =
            
                                To: 
                         =
       EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com 
                                Sent: 
   =

                 =
               Subject: 
                                Re: [EVP-ITC] File=
 uploading rules
                                

                        =
        
                                
                                
=
                                
                                
         =
                       The kind of compression that 
                      =
          occurs during an email attachment is "lossless": 
               =
                 it compress the file cleverly without losing 
            =
                    information.=A0 For example, if I had a 
              =
                  program in some .exe files, and I sent it over 
         =
                       email, it could compress it.=A0 But if it 
         =
                       lost even one bit, the resulting exe file would 
   =
                             not execute again after it was uncompressed on=
 
                                the other side.

This kind of compression=
 
                                does things like looking for common patte=
rns in 
                                the file, and replacing them with a=
 token.=A0 
                                A rough example would be if it =
found "Howdy 
                                Neighbor" in a file 20 times,=
 it could replace 
                                all the occurances with =
say $HN1.=A0 And also 
                                write a little dicti=
onary in there someplace 
                                that says "$HN1=
=3DHowdy Neighbor".

When the 
                                file gets to=
 its destination it can be 
                                uncompressed, a=
nd all occurences of $HN1 are 
                                replaced wit=
h "Howdy Neighbor".=A0 So it was 
                                compresse=
d (instead of 14 characters each, it 
                                only =
needed 4, plus the dictionary), but lost no 
                              =
  data.

Some formats, like jpeg and mp3. 
                                =
are not lossless.=A0 Depending on the level 
                              =
  of compression, some level of data is lost, and 
                        =
        so cannot be recovered or reconstructed 
                          =
      later.

Rick

                                Another 
                              =
  thing:
                                =A0
                              =
  I recently 
                                found this out. When you emai=
l a file, if it is 
                                not saved as a compress=
ed format, the email 
                                filtering process wil=
l actually compress the 
                                file automatically=
.
                                =A0
                                So ev=
en if 
                                you have attached a wav. file, it wi=
ll loose 
                                resolution over the email process=
. It will not 
                                sound exactly the same as th=
e original wav. 
                                file. How much it differs =
depends on the size of 
                                the file you are at=
taching. If it is a 
                                very=A0large file, it =
will sound much 
                                different.
               =
                 =A0
                                The only 
            =
                    exception to this is if the wav. file is small 
       =
                         enough that the filtering process will ignore 
   =
                             it. It has to be pretty small though, like und=
er 
                                1=A0MB (I am not exactly sure of the 
 =
                               threshold).
                                =
=A0
                                The best way 
                         =
       to share files over the internet=A0if you 
                         =
       want them as close to the original as possible 
                    =
            is to upload them directly to a 
                              =
  website.
                                =A0

 Original Message -----

           =
                     Rj

m

unday, May 10, 2009 10:54 AM

            =
                    

                                
                    =
            
                                
                             =
   
                                
                                
Pixel=
ization doesn't clean-up 
                                the data: it repl=
aces it.=A0 Imagine taking a 
                                picture of a =
field of flowers, and beginning to 
                                add lev=
els or pixelization to the picture.=A0 
                                Soo=
n, you would not be able to tell there were 
                              =
  flowers there at all.=A0 You would see a lot 
                           =
     of colored blocks.

Or in the other 
                                d=
irection, imagine you are looking at a 
                                com=
petely randomize bunch of pixes on your 
                                sc=
reen: a complete screen of truely random 
                                s=
tatic snow.=A0 Pixelizing this, after a 
                                wh=
ile, you would again start to see colored 
                                =
blocks.

What's happening is that it is 
                                pr=
ocessing an area of the image, taking (for 
                               =
 instance) the average value of that entire area, 
                        =
        and replacing all the blocks in that area with 
                   =
             the average.=A0 In video processing, this 
                   =
             would result in a field of multi-colored flowers 
            =
                    being replaced by, for instance, a big 
               =
                 greyish-bluish block, with no resemblance to 
            =
                    flowers.=A0 In the noise example, it maybe 
           =
                     replace all the random pixels with another big 
      =
                          greyish-bluish block.=A0 If you did not know 
   =
                             beforehand what the original picture was, you =

                                couldn't tell whether your pixelized image=
 was 
                                really a field of flowers, a chevy, t=
he sky with 
                                clouds, or a random bunch of p=
ixels.

It 
                                works the same with the sound f=
iles.=A0 
                                Taking something as complex as sp=
eech, and 
                                replacing frequencies with their=
 averages, loses 
                                the speech the farther yo=
u go, until you head 
                                strange fluctuating s=
quare waves.=A0 Doing 
                                the same to random s=
tatic will eventually 
                                produce the same thi=
ng.=A0 And random 
                                fluctuating square waves=
 can sound a bit like 
                                speech - or at least=
, you could have fun sharing 
                                with each oth=
er what you thing they 'sound 
                                like'.

       =
                         Be a bit careful of formats like 
                =
                mp3 if you are doing a detailed analysis of the 
          =
                      sounds though.=A0=A0 While some formats 
            =
                    (like wav) can store the audio very close to the 
     =
                           way it was recorded, formats like mp3 compress 
=
                                the file, and in so doing lose some of the =
sonic 
                                details.=A0 This may not be a big de=
al in 
                                music, where the audio is fairly cle=
ar to begin 
                                with.=A0 But with sound source=
s with a lot of 
                                noise (like evps), this ca=
n not only obscure any 
                                real sounds, but pi=
xelize non-sounds (like white 
                                noise) and m=
ake them start to sound like 
                                speech.

So m=
p3 might be good for sharing 
                                the data, onc=

                <td valign=3D"top">They are =
not necessarily the same bytes, but I 
                  was proposing a qu=
ick check just to see if the files were in 
                  the same ball=
park.  Look at it the other way: if the 
                  number of b=
ytes were DIFFERENT, than you'd know the files HAD 
                  chang=
ed, and you could stop testing.  But if the number 
                  =
of bytes are the same, it tends to indicate the files are 
                =
  likely the same, but you still need a low level file 
                  c=
omparison to be sure.<br><br>My method is to compare the 
                 =
 files using the CMP command in unix.  There are many 
               =
   programs to compare files, but you have to be careful not to 
          =
        use one that does a line-by-line compare (or a comparison 
        =
          meant for text files), since text files can be different at a 
  =
                low level, but look essential the same in an editor (becaus=
e 
                  of the way spaces and tabs and new lines work between =
editors 
                  and platforms).<br><br>But anyway, the way to co=
mpare is with 
                  a program that can compare binary files, n=
ot text 
                  files.<br><br><br>--- On <b>Sun, 5/10/09, April =
Abercrombie

gt;</i></b>

                          <td valign=3D"top">A file's conte=
nt, it's integrity, is 
                            simply the bytes (and t=
heir bits) in the file.  
                            If the file's co=
ntent integrity is changed, that is, 
                            by defini=
tion, changing the bytes.  If the 
                            bytes i=
n there are not changed, then that integrity 
                            h=
as not changed.<br><br>It is possible to mess with 
                       =
     other things about a file (like its name, its 
                       =
     suffix, or its ownership) but this does not effect 
                  =
          the contents, and so would not affect that 
                     =
       integrity, or the sound of the file (assuming you 
                 =
           could read it at all after changing the ownership, 
            =
                or the suffix, etc).<br><br>When you do your tests, 
      =
                      if you cannot do a bit level comparison, I would 
   =
                         recommend at least checking the file sizes.  =
If 
                            they are identical, there is a very high pr=
obability 
                            that the content has not 
          =
                  changed.<br><br><br><br><br>--- On <b>Sun, 5/10/09, 
    =
                        April Abercrombie <i><april@abercrombiegh 
     =
